intro: Bunium cylindricum var. brachycarpum, commonly known as the narrow-fruited bishop's weed, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to central and southern Europe. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its compound umbels and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in open woodlands or along roadsides. Its small, greenish-yellow flowers appear in early summer, followed by small, cylindrical fruits. The leaves are finely divided and have a distinctive, pungent odor, which is a common trait among members of its family.
